title: Domain 2.1: Summarize various security measures and their purposes.
content:
üîê Physical Security

  • Access Control Vestibule: A controlled entry point that requires authentication (e.g., card reader, fingerprint scanner).
  • Badge Reader: Uses an identification card or badge to control access to secured areas.
  • Video Surveillance: Cameras installed to monitor and record activities, deterring crime and identifying perpetrators.
  • Alarm Systems: Detect unauthorized entry or breaches, triggering alerts or contacting authorities.
  • Motion Sensors: Detect movement and trigger alerts in a designated area.
  • Door Locks: Electronic or mechanical mechanisms to control access.
  • Equipment Locks: Prevent theft or tampering of hardware, especially in public/shared spaces.
  • Guards: Security personnel who monitor systems and patrol facilities.
  • Bollards: Posts that prevent vehicle access to protected areas.
  • Fences: Perimeter barriers to prevent unauthorized physical access.

üë• Physical Security for Staff

  • Key Fobs: Small electronic devices for secure access.
  • Smart Cards: Cards with embedded chips for identification/access.
  • Keys: Traditional mechanical access tools.
  • Biometrics: Access via physical traits like fingerprints or facial recognition.

üîí Logical Security

  • Principle of Least Privilege: Limit user/system access to only what is needed.
  • Access Control Lists (ACLs): Define who can access a resource and how.
  • Multifactor Authentication (MFA): Requires two or more verification methods (e.g., password + fingerprint).
  • Email: Secure accounts with encryption, strong passwords, and MFA.
  • Hard Token: Physical device generating time-based login codes.
  • Soft Token: App-based code generator on a smartphone.
  • SMS: Sends authentication codes via text message.
  • Voice Call: Sends codes by phone call.
  • Authenticator Application: Apps like Google Authenticator for MFA.

üì± Mobile Device Management (MDM)

  • Login Script: Auto-run scripts to configure devices on login.
  • Domain: Centralized device/user management network.
  • Group Policy/Updates: Enforce rules and push updates.
  • Organizational Units: Logical groups for targeted policy application.
  • Home Folder: Network folder for storing user data.
  • Folder Redirection: Redirects user folders to a network location.
  • Security Groups: Define security permissions per user/device group.

üîê Active Directory (AD)

  • Login Script: Scripts that run at user login for environment setup.
  • Domain: A managed group of devices/resources with centralized control.
  • Group Policy/Updates: Define and enforce system/user policies.
  • Organizational Units (OUs): Organize AD objects by group/department.
  • Home Folder: Server-based personal storage folder.
  • Folder Redirection: Stores Documents/Desktop folders on a network location.
  • Security Groups: Apply access control across users and devices.
